summary: This is a joint letter from the prosecution and defense in the Ghislaine Maxwell case regarding procedures for protecting witness identities at trial. It outlines proposed nomenclature for witnesses, voir dire procedures, jury instructions, and handling of sealed exhibits. The document also includes a transcript excerpt from a court proceeding where the judge denied a defense motion for a mistrial and issued a jury instruction about witness name protection.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, addressed in the letter and making rulings in the transcript excerpt.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case referenced throughout the document (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell).

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who signed the submission letter.

persons.name: Judge Garaufis
persons.context: Judge in the Eastern District of New York who presided over United States v. Raniere; his jury instruction on witness anonymity is cited as a model.

persons.name: MS. PENZA
persons.context: Government attorney speaking in the court transcript, responding to the judge's questions and requests.

persons.name: MR. AGNIFILO
persons.context: Defense attorney speaking in the court transcript, objecting to the judge's proposed jury instruction.

persons.name: Denise Parisi
persons.context: Court reporter certified for the transcript excerpt included in the document.

connections.description: MR. AGNIFILO is acting as defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, objecting to procedures and making a motion for mistrial on her behalf.
Both are prosecutors representing the United States in the case against Ghislaine Maxwell.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal trial of defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Both are United States District Judges; Judge Nathan's court is considering a jury instruction modeled on one given by Judge Garaufis in a prior case.

events.title: Pretrial Conference
events.description: Court directed parties to file a joint letter regarding protections for witness identities at trial.

events.title: Trial Begin Date
events.description: Scheduled start date for the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Defense Motion for Mistrial
events.description: Defense moved for a mistrial, arguing issues with witness name protection procedures were not tenable. The motion was denied by Judge Nathan.

events.title: Court Issues Jury Instruction on Anonymity
events.description: Judge Nathan issued a jury instruction explaining that witnesses use first names only to protect privacy, but their full names are known to the court, government, and defendant.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
Eastern District of New York (referenced for prior case)
keyFacts: The prosecution and defense agreed on procedures to protect witness identities at Ghislaine Maxwell's trial, including using pseudonyms or first names only for certain witnesses.
Judge Alison J. Nathan denied a defense motion for a mistrial related to witness identity protection issues, opting instead to cure any problems with a jury instruction.
The trial was scheduled to begin on November 29, 2021.

The prosecution requested that all exhibits containing witness identifying information be sealed or redacted, and proposed providing jurors with individual binders for such exhibits to prevent public viewing.
The defense proposed an alternative jury instruction on witness anonymity, emphasizing media attention and witness choice, but the judge implemented her own version.
